Award.AwardTitle: EXP: Collaborative Research: A Personalized Storyteller Companion to Promote Preschooler Language Skills

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Early language ability, including vocabulary skills and oral language knowledge during preschool, is an important predictor of children's academic success in subsequent school years. Social robots that can engage children as personalized learning companions hold great promise in augmenting the learning experience of children with parents and teachers. The ultimate goal is to foster the development, learning and promotion of academic achievements and the well-being of children. Such robots offer unique opportunities of guided, personalized and controlled social interaction during the delivery of a desired curriculum. They can play, learn and engage with children in the real world -- physically, socially and emotively. This research project is developing and evaluating an autonomous personalized social robot tutor-companion that can engage preschool children in storytelling activities during a long-term interaction. The research goal is to assess the impact that such an interaction may have on children's language skills development. The project advances the fields of autonomous storytelling generation and analysis, as well as the interaction between autonomous social robots and preschool children to promote learning. Its broader impact is to develop an effective technology that augments the preschool setting that promotes children's language development in a personalized and socially engaging way.

This research project develops and assesses the efficacy of an autonomous, personalized social robot that engages as a learning companion on the language development of pre-school children in the context of storytelling tasks. For this purpose, the research project develops a novel automatic story analysis tool, and a new personalized story generation algorithm, that pushes the envelope of current understanding of free-form storytelling and how fosters the development of early language skills in pre-school aged children. Additionally, the research develops of a fully autonomous social robot that interacts with preschool children in the real-life environment of a preschool. A 9-month longitudinal study at multiple preschool sites is carried out to evaluate the impact of long-term interaction with the storytelling robot on children's engagement and language skill development. The research aims to increase the current understanding of the impact of longitudinal interaction with social robot on children's language development. Ultimately, this can inspire new tools and practices for early pre-literacy and language education (as well as other domains such as STEM) in the home, classroom, and beyond.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A society’s ability to flourish necessarily depends on the development of an active and intellectually-engaged citizenry. Given that one principal factor underlying intellectual development is the acquisition of appropriate language and vocabulary skills early in life, we sought to examine how the use of technologies designed to build vocabulary and language knowledge of English Language Learners during the preschool years might be improved to facilitate learning. This work presents an opportunity for an exceptional synergy among several subfields: robotics and computer science, psychology, and education. Our goal is to truly “push the envelope” in understanding the interactions of young children with cyber technologies to simulate a peer-like learning companion that can successfully foster the development of early language skills of preschoolers over long-term interaction in an educational storytelling context.

In experiments in which we varied the extent to which robots behaved in an emotionally-contingent manner (i.e., expressed emotional cues in ways that were responsive to the children), we found that children preferentially sought information and learned higher level language skills from the robots that behaved in more “human-like” emotionally appropriate ways. We conducted a 3-month study at local public schools, targeting English Language Learners (ELL) and bilingual Kindergarten children between the age of 4-6 years. The sessions consisted of pre- and post-assessments of children’s lexical and syntactic skills, and an interactive session with a social robot telling a story. We studied the effect of personalized interaction by dividing students into two groups: one group interacts with a robot running a personalization algorithm, and another group that interacts with a robot delivering a preselected curriculum. We found evidence that children in the personalized condition were more likely to retell the story with a longer length. They were also more likely to answer robot’s dialogic questions.

In other experiments, we measured children's long-term relationships with social robots: Social robots are being increasingly developed for long-term interactions with children in domains such as healthcare, education, therapy, and entertainment. Because children will not simply have a one-off interaction, we need to deeply understand how children think about social robots over time. However, there are few validated assessments for measuring young children's long-term relationships. As part of the long-term study, we implemented a variety of assessments that could be used in this context, with the goal of enabling long-term child-robot interaction research. 

We also set out to develop a personalization algorithm for selecting the right content for children in the personalized condition based on the history of interactions. Given the range of the lexical and syntactic complexity output possible, the algorithm selects all possible storybook candidates from the corpus. Within these storybooks, the robot selects the story that possesses the most similar words from the previous storybook the child exhibited a strong engagement signal towards. We found that the variance between each child’s policy grew larger over the sessions, indicating the policy was adapting and personalizing to each child interaction.  

Of import, the robotic platform we developed is one that can be controlled remotely, allowing the system to be placed in different environments, such as the child's home or school, or even medical areas where issues of mobility or immunosuppression make it difficult for direct interaction with instructors. We believe that the ability for an instructor to be co-present with a child learner in the form of a robotic avatar (as opposed to screen-based telecommunication solely) could offer substantial benefits in learning by increasing the truly social aspects of the environment in several ways. Indeed, our work demonstrates how the human mind implicitly makes use of and responds to social cues emitted by a robot in the same way as it does to similar cues emitted by a human.

Given the growing recognition that the social aspects of a child’s environment are central to her ability to learn rapidly and efficiently, we developed robots that, through incorporating signals that the mind implicitly uses to ascertain the intentions and motivations of others, is capable of serving as true embodiments of a human instructor. Our goal is to design a system for greater outreach and increased efficiency among instructors or parents who would utilize the robotic platform for teaching language skills to young children that are key to Kindergarten readiness. The robots can be placed in remote locations to bring key learning experiences to children. Such benefits not only increase the number of children that can be reached but potentially increase children's learning and developmental outcomes.
